trans-unit.source: How to log on to the virtual machine after you create it
trans-unit.target: How to log on to the virtual machine after you create it

trans-unit.source: To manage the settings of the virtual machine and the applications that run on the machine, you can use an SSH client.
trans-unit.target: To manage the settings of the virtual machine and the applications that run on the machine, you can use an SSH client.

trans-unit.source: To do this, you must install an SSH client on your computer that you want to use to access the virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: To do this, you must install an SSH client on your computer that you want to use to access the virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: There are many SSH client programs that you can choose from.
trans-unit.target: There are many SSH client programs that you can choose from.

trans-unit.source: The following are possible choices:
trans-unit.target: The following are possible choices:

trans-unit.source: If you are using a computer that is running a Windows operating system, you might want to use an SSH client such as PuTTY.
trans-unit.target: If you are using a computer that is running a Windows operating system, you might want to use an SSH client such as PuTTY.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [PuTTY Download](http://www.chiark.greenend.org.uk/~sgtatham/putty/download.html).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [PuTTY Download](http://www.chiark.greenend.org.uk/~sgtatham/putty/download.html).

trans-unit.source: If you are using a computer that is running a Linux operating system, you might want to use an SSH client such as OpenSSH.
trans-unit.target: If you are using a computer that is running a Linux operating system, you might want to use an SSH client such as OpenSSH.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [OpenSSH](http://www.openssh.org/).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [OpenSSH](http://www.openssh.org/).

trans-unit.source: This tutorial shows you how to use the PuTTY program to access the virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: How to attach a data disk to the new virtual machine
trans-unit.target: How to attach a data disk to the new virtual machine

trans-unit.source: Your application may need to store data.
trans-unit.target: Your application may need to store data.

trans-unit.source: To set this up, you attach a data disk to the virtual machine that you previously created.
trans-unit.target: To set this up, you attach a data disk to the virtual machine that you previously created.

trans-unit.source: The easiest way to do this is to attach an empty data disk to the machine.
trans-unit.target: The easiest way to do this is to attach an empty data disk to the machine.

trans-unit.source: On Linux, the Resource Disk is typically managed by the Azure Linux Agent and automatically mounted to **/mnt/resource** (or **/mnt** on Ubuntu images).
trans-unit.target: On Linux, the Resource Disk is typically managed by the Azure Linux Agent and automatically mounted to **/mnt/resource** (or **/mnt** on Ubuntu images).

trans-unit.source: On the other hand, on Linux the data disk might be named by the kernel as `/dev/sdc`, and users will need to partition, format and mount that resource.
trans-unit.target: On the other hand, on Linux the data disk might be named by the kernel as `/dev/sdc`, and users will need to partition, format and mount that resource.

trans-unit.source: Please see the [Azure Linux Agent User Guide](../articles/virtual-machines/virtual-machines-linux-agent-user-guide.md) for more information.
trans-unit.target: Please see the [Azure Linux Agent User Guide](../articles/virtual-machines/virtual-machines-linux-agent-user-guide.md) for more information.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] Don’t store data on the resource disk.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] Don’t store data on the resource disk.

trans-unit.source: This disk provides temporary storage for applications and processes and is used to store data that you don’t need to keep, such as swap files.
trans-unit.target: This disk provides temporary storage for applications and processes and is used to store data that you don’t need to keep, such as swap files.

trans-unit.source: Data disks reside Azure Storage as .vhd files in page blobs and provide storage redundancy to protect your data.
trans-unit.target: Data disks reside Azure Storage as .vhd files in page blobs and provide storage redundancy to protect your data.

trans-unit.source: For details, see [About Disks and Images in Azure](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/jj672979.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For details, see [About Disks and Images in Azure](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/jj672979.aspx).

trans-unit.source: If you have not already done so, sign in to the Azure Management Portal.
trans-unit.target: If you have not already done so, sign in to the Azure Management Portal.

trans-unit.source: Click **Virtual Machines**, and then select the **MyTestVM1** virtual machine that you previously created.
trans-unit.target: Click **Virtual Machines**, and then select the **MyTestVM1** virtual machine that you previously created.

trans-unit.source: On the command bar, click **Attach**, and then click **Attach Empty Disk**.

trans-unit.source: All you have to do is enter the size that you want for the disk.
trans-unit.target: All you have to do is enter the size that you want for the disk.
